pros:
Nice work environment
Friendly co-workers
Summer schedule
Good benefits
cons: I have no complaints :-)

pros: Very flexible hours. The guy in charge is great.
cons: I can't think of any cons.

job_title: Associate Professor of English in Florence, SC
pros: Some of the most dedicated faculty in the world. Great collaboration and support from both faculty and staff. Lots of opportunity for research funding and building teaching expertise in areas you maybe didn't focus on in graduate school. Teaching is valued as a real strength, as is university service.
cons: A lot of "one person department"s--a single people running essential functions that other schools would have teams of employees to address. This reduces administrative bloat, but faculty members' "university service" ends up doing the work of a full time position elsewhere. It works well until someone retires, leaves for a better position, or becomes suddenly ill. As you'd expect in SC in the public sector, the pay is below average for every position, even compared to similar schools.

pros: Lots of internal funds for research and scholarship. Nice students. Commitment to diversity among student body.
cons: Low pay across board, salary parity and inversion issues rampant. Underprepared students. Rampant favoritism from administration. High crime community.

job_title: Assistant Professor of Marketing in Florence, SC
pros: They take care of their employees and very collegial
cons: Salary and benefits are very low

review_title: Great intermediate professional skills development but hard work
pros: Housing coverage + pay, Develop multidisciplinary skills for career, Interaction with residential community, freedom of program development opportunities, opportunity to mentor residents and new hires
cons: Long sometimes unexpected hours including weekends, Upfront pay is minimal despite Housing coverage, Have to deal with some very difficult personalities and lazy people, prepare for the unexpected especially with residents

review_title: Like the sign says, a great place to work
job_title: Vice President, Communications in Florence, SC
pros: The atmosphere is collegial, the cause is good, the administration pays a lot of attention to employee needs, etc. It has encompasses the safety and security of a government job.
cons: FMU has done well with providing employees consistent salary increases and bonuses, but much of the budget is controlled by the state legislature. Funding may be affected by statewide economic and political considerations.

pros: Here at FMU the staff is amazing! It is a great work place environment and great for any recent college graduate!
cons: There are no cons I can think of at the moment.

pros: Only work for half a day, Instructions were easy
cons: Doesn't pay enough for the hours.

pros: Nice work environment. Kind people and a beautiful campus.
cons: No room for advancement unless you have or are pursuing a graduate degree. Staff members are much less valued than faculty members.

job_title: Student Services Coordinator II in Florence, SC
pros: Sense of community, students listen well
cons: Extremely low pay for years of service

pros: Good colleagues, close knit work community
cons: Poor salary, heavy handed administration

pros: Friendly people; good work-life balance
cons: Extremely low compensation; little incentive to seek promotion as they are not associated with salary increases.

pros: It’s small. The students are fantastic.
cons: It’s so small and they have no money to fix issues with infrastructure

review_title: Dr. Carter has changed the landscape of the University
job_title: Had Several Over My Tenure in Florence, SC
pros: FMU contributes significantly to the Pee Dee area.  Proud to be part of the organization that is integral to this area.
cons: Although the benefits are exceptional, the pay is really low.  Hard to work there on that salary and raise a family.

pros: Working for the university provided a flexible schedule. My supervisor was always willing to work with me on any issues I had.
cons: There were not many cons I experienced. Sometimes the expectations set by my boss's boss were difficult to meet. Also, sometimes the requirements of my supervisors multiple roles would conflict.

pros: Helping students, planning events, being creative.
cons: offensively low pay (less than 24 w/bachelors degree)  while faculty make 150,000+ and cant figure out how to print a pdf.

pros: Meeting new people constantly and having those people give advice and help you to understand your job a little better. It's really like a family in the sense that everyone is out to help and progress!
cons: Adjusting to work in the summer-time. Less students/faculty/staff = less technology being "broken", but also means time to get ahead and start on a new project.

pros: Small, pretty campus with some of the best faculty in the state. Generally a very hard-working and helpful staff.
cons:
Very poor salaries for staff compared with elsewhere in the state. the earning discrepancy between leadership and lower staff is enormous, and disturbing in my opinion.
Students who succeed receive a great education, but there is very little student involvement outside of class compared to nearby universities.

pros: The people who work here for the most part, are very nice people to work with.
cons: Location not good. Growth only in some areas, not well rounded.

pros:
Usually get a bonus every year as well as a raise.
Laid back atmosphere.
Great amount of vacation and sick time.
cons: No real opportunities for career advancement.

pros: Good benefits and insurance for full time employees, friendly people
cons: I don’t see any cons so far.

pros: FMU has a great administration and excellent facilities
cons: Pay is lower than in the private sector.

pros: great work environment and room to grow as a worker
